studies.title: Flow cytometry has a significant impact on the cellular metabolome (CE-MS assay)
studies.description:
The characterization of specialized cell subpopulations in a heterogeneous tissue is essential for understanding organ function in health and disease. A popular method of cell isolation is fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) based on probes that bind surface or intracellular markers. In this study, we analyse the impact of FACS on the cell metabolome of mouse peritoneal macrophages. Compared with directly pelleted macrophages, FACS-treated cells had an altered content of metabolites related to the plasma membrane, activating a mechanosensory signalling cascade causing inflammation-like stress. The procedure also triggered alterations related to energy consumption and cell damage. The observed changes mostly derive from the physical impact on cells during their passage through the instrument. These findings provide evidence of FACS-induced biochemical changes, which should be taken into account in the design of robust metabolic assays of cells separated by flow cytometry.

The CE-MS assay is reported in the current study MTBLS633.
The General LC-MS assay is reported in MTBLS629.
The Lipidomic LC-MS assay is reported in MTBLS631.
The GC-MS assay is reported in MTBLS634.

Linked Studies: MTBLS629 MTBLS631 MTBLS634

publications.title: Flow Cytometry Has a Significant Impact on the Cellular Metabolome.
publications.authorList: Binek A, Rojo D, Godzien J, Rupérez FJ, Nuñez V, Jorge I, Ricote M, Vázquez J, Barbas C.

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description: Thioglycollate solution (3%) was injected into the peritoneal cavity of 12-week-old C57BL/6 mice to elicit the accumulation of macrophages. Animals were sacrificed 72 h after the injection, and the accumulated macrophages were collected by peritoneal lavage with 10 m sterile PBS. After centrifugation (1400 rpm, 5 min, 4 °C) and washing in 5 ml PBS (1400 rpm, 5 min, 4 °C), cells were counted under the microscope, divided into 4 equal volumes, and centrifuged (1400 rpm, 5 min, 4 °C). After counting and washing the cell pellet in the Ctrl sample was immediately snap-frozen in liq. N2. For the Ab sample, the cell pellet was resuspended in blocking buffer containing anti-CD16/CD32 (Mouse Fc Block, nr.553141, BD Bioscience - Pharmingen), incubated on ice for 20 min, and subsequently washed in PBS. The cells were then incubated on ice for 20 min with PerCP-Cy5.5-labeled anti-CD45 (nr.550994, BD Bioscience - Pharmingen) and washed in PBS. After the final washing step, the cell pellet was immediately frozen in liq. N2. The sorted unlabelled cell sample (Sort) and the sorted immunostained cell sample (Ab+Sort) were prepared following the protocols for the Ctrl and Ab groups, respectively, but instead of snap freezing, the cell pellets were resuspended in PBS for FACS. The complete cell populations were sorted in a BD FACSAria II flow cytometer and the data analysed with FlowJo software (FlowJo LLC) (see Figure S6 in the paper associated with this study). No sub-populations were isolated in order to ensure that sample composition remained comparable to the Ctrl and Ab groups and to identify biochemical changes induced solely by the sorting process. After collection, cells from the Sort and Ab+Sort group were pelleted, frozen in liq. N2, and stored at -80 °C until fingerprinting analysis.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Since biological replicates differed slightly in cell number, the extraction solvent volume was calculated according to the cell pellet mass, thus ensuring between-sample normalization of metabolite concentrations (see Table S1 in the paper associated with this study). On the day of analysis, cell pellets were thawed and doubly extracted by sequential additions of i) MeOH:MTBE (4:1, v/v) and ii) MeOH:H2O (4:1, v/v). Each solvent addition was followed by 3 cycles of freeze/thawing (liq. N2 /cold-water bath, 10 s), sonication (15 W, 6 min), vortexing (1 min), and centrifugation (16,000 x g, 10 min, 4 °C). Equal volumes of the supernatants from i and ii were then mixed and aliquoted for subsequent analysis.

For CE-MS, 200 µl of the supernatant mix were evaporated to dryness in a Speedvac Concentrator and the sample was reconstituted in 60 µl MilliQ® water containing an internal standard (0.2 mM L-methionine sulfone) and 0.1 M FA.

QC samples are required at the beginning of the sequence to stabilize the system and throughout the analytical runs at periodic intervals to monitor variations in signals over time. Individual QC samples were therefore prepared independently for each analytical platform by pooling and mixing equal volumes of each sample. After gentle vortexing, the mixes were transferred to analytical vials.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description: For CE-MS, metabolite profiles were obtained by capillary electrophoresis (CE), (7100 Agilent) coupled to TOF (6224 Agilent). The CE mode was controlled by the ChemStation software (B.04.03, Agilent), and the MS mode was controlled by the Mass Hunter Workstation Data Analysis software (B.02.01, Agilent). Separations occurred in a fused-silica capillary (Agilent: total length, 100 cm; i.d., 50 μm). All separations were performed in normal polarity with a background electrolyte containing 1.0 M formic acid in 10% MeOH (v/v) at 20 °C. New capillaries were preconditioned with a flush of 1.0 M NaOH for 30 min, followed by MilliQ water for 30 min and the background electrolyte for 30 min. Before each analysis, the capillary was conditioned with a 5 min flush of the background electrolyte. The sheath liquid (6 µl/min) was MeOH:H2O (1:1) containing 1.0 mM FA with 2 reference masses 121.0509 (purine, detected m/z [C5H4N4+H]+) and 922.0098 (HP, detected m/z [C18H18O6N3P3F24+H]+), which allowed for correction and higher mass accuracy in the MS. The samples were hydrodynamically injected at 50 mBar for 50 s. Stacking was performed by applying the background electrolyte at 100 mBar for 10 s. The separation voltage was 30 kV, the internal pressure was 25 mBar, and the analyses were performed in 28 min.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: For CE-MS, data were collected on a TOF mass spectrometer (6224 Agilent). The MS parameters were as follows: fragmentor voltage 150 V, skimmer voltage 65 V, octopole voltage 750 V, drying gas temperature 200 °C, flow rate 10 l/min, and capillary voltage 3500 V. The data were acquired in positive mode with a full scan from m/z 85 to 1000 at a rate of 1.41 scans per second. Samples were analysed in randomized runs, during which they were incubated in an autosampler at 4 °C. The analytical run was set up to start with the analysis of 5 QCs followed by the samples; a QC sample was injected between blocks of 4 unblinded samples until the end of the run.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
In CE-MS, data were deconvoluted with the Molecular Feature Extraction algorithm in the MassHunter Qualitative Analysis software (B.06.00, Agilent). Raw data were aligned with Mass Profiler Professional (version 13.0, Agilent). In order to perform the differential analysis on the metabolomics data, in all the platforms the raw variables were then filtered according to a modification of the filtering criteria previously proposed[1]: variables present in at least 50% of the samples of each experimental group and either i) present in at least 80% of the QCs that yielded a variation coefficient <30% or ii) present in <20% of the QCs. Principal component analysis (PCA) models (see Figure S1 in the paper associated with this study) were subsequently built using the SIMCA-P+ software (12.0.1.0, Umetrics). Next, after replacement of missing values by k-means nearest neighbour analysis according to the criteria previously published[2], the Mann-Whitney U test was used for all comparisons (i.e., Ctrl vs Ab; Ctrl vs Sort; and Ctrl vs Ab+Sort) followed by the Benjamini-Hochberg post hoc correction (p < 0.05). Missing values were imputed and statistical comparisons made using in-house built scripts for MATLAB (7.10.0.499, MathWorks, Natick, MA, USA).

Ref:
[1] Godzien J, Alonso-Herranz V, Barbas C, Armitage EG. Controlling the quality of metabolomics data: new strategies to get the best out of the QC sample. Metabolomics 2014, 11, (3), 518-528. doi:10.1007/s11306-014-0712-4.
[2] Armitage EG, Godzien J, Alonso-Herranz V, López-Gonzálvez Á, Barbas C. Missing value imputation strategies for metabolomics data. Electrophoresis. 2015 Dec;36(24):3050-60. doi:10.1002/elps.201500352. PMID:26376450

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description: In CE-MS, the resulting list of accurate masses that significantly differed between groups was searched using the CEU Mass Mediator search tool (http://biolab.uspceu.com/mediator; error ± 5 ppm) to obtain tentative identifications. Each identification was then manually curated based on MS adducts for lipids identified by LC-MS and on the in-source fragmentation pattern for metabolites identified by CE-MS. When appropriate, the elution order was considered in order to discard spurious identifications. The biological role of identified compounds was evaluated and irrelevant identifications such as pesticides, drugs, or impossible chemical structures were excluded. In the final list (see Table S3 in the paper associated with this study), metabolites are reported according to the criteria of the Metabolomics Standards Initiative, with a confidence level in grade 2 (putatively annotated compounds). Variation between experimental conditions is reported as log2 FC, always relative to control. The number of hits per analytical platform that passed each step is listed in Table S2 in the paper associated with this study.
